description: From Middle English implien, emplien, borrowed from Old French emplier, from Latin implicare (“to infold, involve”), from in (“in”) + plicare (“to fold”). Doublet of employ and implicate.

verbs.description: imply (third-person singular simple present implies, present participle implying, simple past and past participle implied)

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a proposition) to have as a necessary consequence
examples: The proposition that "all dogs are mammals" implies that my dog is a mammal.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a person) to suggest by logical inference
examples: When I state that your dog is brown, I am not implying that all dogs are brown.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a person or proposition) to hint; to insinuate; to suggest tacitly and avoid a direct statement
examples: What do you mean "we need to be more careful with hygiene"? Are you implying that I don't wash my hands?
